caption:
This photograph captures a man at work on a large fishing net spread out on the ground. The individual is focused on mending or adjusting the net, seated near its center while handling a smaller section of netting. He is dressed in a dark short-sleeve shirt and dark pants, creating a visual contrast against the pale color of the net.

The setting appears to be an outdoor area by a waterfront, likely part of a marina or a similar logistic point for boating and fishing operations. In the background, various nautical and industrial elements can be observed: a boat in a state of disrepair, a trailer, and other maritime-related equipment clutter the area, suggesting ongoing labor and activity. Behind this, a calm body of water and lush greenery lining the far shore provide a natural backdrop, adding to the rustic, work-oriented ambiance of the scene.

This mix of nature and human activity conveys a sense of practical engagement with the environment, typical of places where fishing is a significant part of daily life and economy. The open sky above and the absence of modern technology in the immediate vicinity emphasize the timeless nature of the scene.
title: In the spring of 1973, the Mississippi River reached its highest level in more than 150 years. Unprecedented flooding occurred throughout the river basin. Particularly affected were the marsh areas below New Orleans and the entire Atchafalaya River basin. Lafitte shrimp fisherman weaves net. Three weeks earlier this area was under flood water.
